subject: RE: [junit] varying amount of time calculated using JUNIT 3.8 as well as 4.1
msgSnippet: Shubha, You re just experiencing natural variations in processing time, which will be caused by your CPU doing something else while you re app is running.
messageBody:
Shubha,



You're just experiencing natural variations in processing time, which
will be caused by your CPU doing something else while you're app is
running. This could be the Java GC running, OS paging to disk or just
another application taking up some of the CPU. Short of having a true
real-time system you're always going to see this.



________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Shubha B S
Sent: 13 March 2007 05:48
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] varying amount of time calculated using JUNIT 3.8 as
well as 4.1



Hi,

I have tried a simple calculator sample Calculator.java, another test
which tests the Calculator is CalculatorTest.java. In this I am trying
to calculate the time taken to execute the test method. I observed
varying times in msecs (2000, 2015, 2016). Can anybody tell what is the
reason behind?

Calculator.java

package calculator;

public class Calculator {
private static int result;

public void add(int n) {
result = result + n;
}
}

CalculatorTest.java

package calculator;
import calculator.Calculator;
import org.junit.Before;
import org.junit.Test;
import static org.junit.Assert.*;
public class CalculatorTest
{
private static Calculator calculator =
new Calculator();

@Before
public void clearCalculator() {
calculator.clear();
}

@Test
public void add() throws InterruptedException {
long token = System.currentTimeMillis();
Thread.sleep(2000);
calculator.add(1);
calculator.add(1);
assertEquals(calculator.getResult(), 2);
System.out.println(" Time taken to execute:" +
(System.currentTimeMillis()-token)) ;
}
}

thanks
Shubha
